messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Both sides of the tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Yeah, green onions, no doubt about it. One big udon noodle and chopped green onions. That is all. Gordon ...
messages.messageBody:
Yeah, green onions, no doubt about it. One big udon noodle and chopped
green onions. That is all.

Gordon

On 2004.1.9, at 10:14 AM, Jim Gilbert wrote:

> >It's an udon noodle.
>
> >Gordon
>
> And the curlicues are chopped green onions?
>
> At first those small curved figures looked like the usual
> representation of birds, but they aren't that.  The two at the right
> look like they are growing organically out of the rim.  They would fit
> with small tendrils coming off of a vine.  Some karakusa motifs are
> drawn like that.  The joined curls at the top are very strange though,
> as is the upper end of the main "noodle."  Strange one.
>
> Jim
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Both sides of the tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: ... And the curlicues are chopped green onions? At first those small curved figures looked like the usual representation of birds, but they aren t that.  The
messages.messageBody:
>It's an udon noodle.

>Gordon

And the curlicues are chopped green onions?

At first those small curved figures looked like the usual representation of birds, but they aren't that. The two at the right look like they are growing organically out of the rim. They would fit with small tendrils coming off of a vine. Some karakusa motifs are drawn like that. The joined curls at the top are very strange though, as is the upper end of the main "noodle." Strange one.

Jim

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
